Dual-atom catalysts (DACs), a natural extension of single-atom catalysts (SACs), have emerged as a prominent focal point in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, particularly in the context of chemical and energy conversion processes. Despite the fact that the catalytic activity of DACs is significantly modulated by the electronic structure of the catalyst, understanding how electron spin states are affected by variations in topology and geometric structure remains challenging and relatively unexplored. Herein, we propose the rational design of stable DACs composed of two iron atoms anchored on pristine graphdiyne (GDY), Fe2-GDYn. A comprehensive and systematic investigation was carried out to elucidate the electronic configuration and spin states involved in the deliberate convergence towards the magnetic ground state, with the aim of uncovering the structure-spin relationship. Through an in-depth analysis of spin populations, electronic localization/delocalization, and the chemical bonding characteristics of the central metal atoms and the GDY skeleton, it was revealed that the spin coupling between the two iron atoms is preponderantly dictated by adjacent short-range Fe-Fe interactions. Conversely, spin decoupling can be attributed to the long-range π-bond component within the linkage. Moreover, geometric and chemical bonding asymmetries were found to induce orbital and spin splitting in iron atoms possessing an electronic configuration of d 8. These findings provide important insights into the relationship between topology and spin, thereby presenting novel strategies for the rational design of spin-manipulated DACs. Graphical Abstract This paper designs 16 Fe-based dual-atom catalysts on graphdiyne (GDY). It reveals the structure-spin relationship, and finds that spin coupling/decoupling is affected by Fe–Fe interactions and GDY's π-bonds parameters. The ORR mechanism is also explored, providing insights for rational catalyst design. Keywords Dual-atom catalysts Graphdiyne Rational design Electronic structure Spin state 1 Introduction Heterogeneous single-atom catalysts (SACs), as a research frontier and hotspot in the field of catalysis and energy conversion, have the advantages of homogeneous active sites, high selectivity, and high reactivity [ 1–5 ]. However, most SACs also suffer from low metal loading, small contact area between single atoms and carrier materials, weak interactions of isolated metal atoms, and lack of adsorption sites, which limit their application in many complex reactions [ 6–9 ]. In recent years, several experimental and theoretical works have pointed out that dual-atom catalysts (DACs), as a natural extension of SACs, have the advantages of large atomic loading, potentially coordinated and controllable interactions between diatomic sites, more versatile active sites, and unique reaction activities [ 10–16 ]. DACs are defined as instances where the distance (d) between two metal atoms is reduced to a certain extent (typically less than 15 Å), leading to interactions between these close metal atoms [ 17,18 ]. This interaction subsequently causes a synergistic adjustment of the electronic structure at the metallic sites. The interactions occurring between the diatomic sites do not simply represent an additive assemblage of the functions inherent to individual atoms. Instead, they play a crucial role in facilitating the modulation of the electronic structure within the catalytic active sites. This, in turn, enhancing the catalytic performance and expanding the scope of catalytic reactions. Such an approach holds the potential for application within a multiplicity of catalytic domains [ 19,20 ]. In SACs, a variety of electronic characteristic parameters, namely metal-support interactions, orbital hybridization, charge transfer, and spin states, are conventionally utilized to modulate and optimize catalytic performance [ 21–26 ]. However, DACs exhibit more complex electronic interactions and synergistic effects. Research findings suggest that DACs can be classified into three distinct categories, predicated upon the distance (d) between metal sites, the mode of connectivity, and the nature of interactions between the two metallic atoms, each demonstrating unique and characteristic features: Isolated DACs with separated metal sites (3 Å < d < 15 Å), wherein one of the diatomic atoms functions as the principal active site, while the other assumes the role of a modulator, exerting an influence on the overall catalytic behavior. Non-metallic atom (N/O) bridged DACs (2 Å < d < 3 Å), which do not involve direct bonding between the metal atoms. Instead, they form diatomic active sites, and the primary focus of mechanistic studies lies in the microscopic coordination environment engendered by the non-metal atoms. And direct dual-metal bonded DACs (2 Å < d < 3 Å), where the catalytic performance is modulated and enhanced by the direct metal-metal bonding synergistic effect, which induces significant alterations in the electronic and geometric properties of the catalyst [ 18,27 ]. At the level of electronic structure, the incorporation of a second metal atom has the potential to substantially modify the electronic structure and spin state of the metal center. Notably, the spin state has emerged as a highly significant factor, as it establishes a critical correlation between the electronic structure and the electrocatalytic performance of catalysts [ 28,29 ]. Several investigations have demonstrated a close correlation between reactivity and magnetic configuration [ 30–33 ]. In particular, FeN x , a commonly studied SAC, exhibits three spin configurations of low-spin, medium-spin and high-spin states, for the central Fe cation, which are attributed to distinct coordination geometries. Among these, the low-spin and medium-spin states were reported to interact with the antibonding π-orbitals of O2 and have high oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) activities [ 24,34,35 ]. In 2021, Jiang and coworkers [ 36 ] proposed the use of the electron spin magnetic moment as a catalytic descriptor to measure linear relationship between the variation in the spin magnetic moment and the ORR activity of Fe SACs loaded on C2N monolayers. Ye et al. [ 37 ] developed a DACs characterized by conjoined MnN4 and FeN4 binuclear sites embedded in a graphite-like structure. Strong short-range electronic interaction between the Mn and Fe sites (FeMn) decouples a pair of electrons in the Fe 3d xy orbital, with one electron exciting into the Fe 3d z 2 orbital, thereby transforming medium spin Fe (III) to a high spin state and facilitating the adsorption of O2 and oxygen-containing intermediates, thus promoting the ORR process. He et al. [ 38 ] demonstrated that introducing a Cu atom (d 10 configuration) in FeCu DACs induces reverse spin polarization of the Fe d z 2 orbital through intermetallic charge transfer. In contrast, FeNi DACs exhibit weakened Fe spin polarization due to competing spin-exchange interactions at the Fe-Ni interface [ 39 ]. Additionally, researchers have found that the spin state of a metal surface significantly impacts the adsorption energy of adsorbates. For iron, cobalt, and nickel surfaces, the adsorption energy for a range of adsorbates is generally higher on non-spin-polarized surfaces compared to spin-polarized surfaces [ 40 ]. The spin state of DACs plays a pivotal role in the catalytic activity of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [ 41 ], carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [ 42 ], nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [ 43 ], oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) [ 44 ], and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [ 45 ]. Nevertheless, despite extensive research on DACs, the rationalization of intermetallic synergistic catalysis should not disregard other structural aspects, even though inter-site distance has been proposed as a descriptor for quantitatively evaluating electronic metal-metal interactions. Furthermore, while numerous exploratory studies have been conducted on spin states and catalytic properties, the relationship between the intrinsic structure and spin properties of active centers in specific systems remains unreported. Previous research has demonstrated that GDY, a unique two-dimensional material with acetylene bonding, heterogeneous charge distribution, a porous architecture, and spatial confinement effects, facilitates stable metal atom loading and significantly enhances metal capacity. This makes GDY an ideal platform for the development of SACs/DACs [ 46–51 ]. In this study, 16 Fe-based DACs were designed using GDY with specific structural features, considering GDY's topology and varying metal loadings. Density functional theory (DFT) analysis revealed that all designed catalysts are thermodynamically stable. A deliberate magnetic ground state convergence strategy was employed to investigate electronic configurations and spin states, clarify the structure-spin relationship. Spin coupling between iron atoms is primarily governed by short-range Fe-Fe interactions, while spin decoupling results from long-range delocalized π-bonding of GDY skeleton. Geometric and bonding asymmetries cause orbital and spin splitting in iron atoms. These findings offer valuable insights into the interplay between topological structures and spin states, suggesting innovative approaches for the rational design of spin-manipulated dual-atom catalysts. 2 Computational details The simulation of the pristine GDY was carried out using a 2 × 2 × 1 supercell model. The inherent triangular micropores in the GDY structure are composed of 18 carbon atoms. In light of the topological architecture of GDY, a comprehensive analysis of the geometric configuration of Fe loading onto GDY was conducted. It was determined that the metal Fe atom positioned at the center of the GDY triangular ring exhibits instability (Fig. S1). The most thermodynamically stable adsorption sites are located at the corners of the triangle, as illustrated by the red quadrangular stars in Fig. 1(a) . When the metal coverage is 0.25, 0.50, and 1.00, the corresponding metal atomic loadings are 11.5 wt%, 20.6 wt%, and 34.1 wt%, respectively. Furthermore, when the metal coverage is set at 0.50 and 1.00, Fe4-GDY and Fe8-GDY exhibit ferromagnetic (FM) characteristics (Fig. S2). However, the metal atomic loading in the currently available DACs supported by GDY typically falls below 20 wt% [ 52 ]. Consequently, 16 Fe DACs were rationally designed, taking into account the topology of GDY and varying metal loadings. These catalyst structures were designated as “Fe2-GDYn”, where “n” represents the serial number of each catalyst structure (n = 0, 1, 2, ……, 15). In these structures, the two iron atoms are labeled as FeI and FeII, respectively, while the carbon atoms directly bonded to Fe are denoted as C1, C2, etc. (Fig. 1(b)). In this work, structure relaxations, single-point (SP) energies, and electronic structures are calculated using DFT as implemented in the Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [ 53,54 ]. The projector-augmented-wave (PAW) pseudopotential was employed to handle the core electrons [ 55 ], while the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used to describe electron interactions [ 56,57 ]. A plane-wave cut-off energy of 500 eV was applied for all calculations. Spin-polarized calculations were performed for all systems, with a convergence criterion for residual forces set to 0.02 eV Å–1. A vacuum space of 15 Å was included to prevent interactions between periodic images. All systems were relaxed in reciprocal space using a k-point grid of 3 × 3 × 1 with the Monkhorst-Pack scheme, and a k-point grid of 9 × 9 × 1 was used for the calculation of the projected density of states (PDOS). The crystal orbital Hamiltonian population (COHP) analysis was utilized to investigate Fe–C bonding characteristics [ 58–60 ]. The free-energy diagram of the ORR was calculated based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model and thermodynamic corrections [ 61,62 ]. The binding energy (E B) of metal atoms was used as the catalyst stability criterion. The binding energy for the two iron atoms adsorbed on the substrate was calculated using the following equation: (1) E B = E Fe2-GDY – E GDY – 2E Fe where E GDY and E Fe2-GDY are the total energies of the substrate without and with the anchored two iron atoms, respectively. Additionally, E Fe represents the average energy of a single iron atom within the face-centered cubic (FCC) iron unit cell. For the detailed spin state analysis, a convergence of the magnetic ground state was initially achieved using the parameters ISPIN = 2 and a default initial MAGMOM for all elements. Subsequently, a more rigorous magnetization ground state convergence was performed with a k-point grid of 9 × 9 × 1 and energy difference of 1.0 × 10–8 eV per atom (Fig. S3), and the initial MAGMOM for the two iron atoms was set to approximately 1.5 times the spin population value from the previous step. Furthermore, we conducted a convergence test of the MAGMOM settings of 2 and 4 (Table S1). The findings demonstrated that the spin configuration of the two Fe atoms remained consistent, and the energy remained essentially stable. This implies that modifications to the initial MAGMOM value—such as multiplying by 1.2 or 1.5—do not substantially influence the spin state or energy of the system. To evaluate the ground state, the energy difference between the ferromagnetic (FM, with the same spin direction of two iron atoms) and antiferromagnetic (AFM, with the opposite spin state between the two iron atoms) configurations calculated using the following equation: (2) ΔE = E AFM – E FM where E AFM denotes the total SP energy of AFM state, in which the initial MAGMOM of two iron atoms, FeI and FeII, were assigned values of 3 and –3, respectively. Meanwhile, E FM represents the total SP energy of FM state, wherein the initial MAGMOM of both iron atoms was set to 3. For qualitative and quantitative analysis of orbital and spin splitting, the d-band center (ε dbc) below the Fermi energy (E F) level was calculated to calibrate the relative orbital energy levels: (3) ɛ d b c = ∫ - ∞ 0 n d ( ɛ ) ɛ d ɛ ∫ - ∞ 0 n d ( ɛ ) d ɛ where n d(ε) is the density of states as a function of energy ε, and ε represents the specific energy level. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Geometric structural properties and rationality of designed Fe DACs The structure of the pristine GDY was first optimized, resulting in a lattice parameter of 9.46 Å, consistent with previously reported value [ 63 ]. The optimized geometry configurations of 16 GDY-supported Fe DACs are shown in Fig. 2 . Our findings reveal that the two iron metal atoms are not co-planar with the GDY but project outward from the plane (as illustrated in Fig. S4 and Fig. 2 side view). The vertical heights of the two iron atoms from the GDY base level are denoted as the first structure descriptor d FeI and d FeII, respectively. Additionally, d ⊥ = |d FeI – d FeII| is defined to evaluate the elevation difference between the two iron sites. As is shown in Table S2, Fe2-GDY1, Fe2-GDY3, and Fe2-GDY4, with d ⊥ value of 0.305, 0.294, and 0.307 Å, respectively, exhibit the largest axial differences among the Fe DACs. Moreover, the straight-line distances d║ between the two metal atoms serve as another geometric descriptor, ranging from 2.430 to 14.015 Å (Fig. 2, red line and taps). For a single metal atom loaded in the cavity of the GDY sp bond, the Fe–C bond lengths range from 1.845 to 2.092 Å, with an average value of 1.910–1.999 (Table S3). Compared to the Pyykkö covalent bond lengths for Fe–C, which are 1.910 Å for a single bond and 1.760 Å for a double bond [ 64,65 ], the FeI–C3, FeI–C4, FeII–C7, and FeII–C8 bonding in Fe2-GDYn (excluding Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3) can be designated as strong bonding intermediate, with the bond lengths within the range demarcated by the Fe–C single and double bond. Consequently, within all configurations except Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3, each iron atom is stabilized by four Fe–C bonds: two with an average bond length of 1.881 Å, which is shorter than the sum of the Pyykkö covalent single bond radii for Fe and C (1.910 Å), while the other two are elongated Fe–C bonds with an averaging length of 1.973 Å [ 66 ]. In the specific cases of Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3, characterized by Fe–Fe distances of 2.430 and 3.662 Å, respectively, the possibility of significant interaction between the two iron atoms cannot be discounted. To assess the stability and rationality of the designed GDY-supported Fe DACs, all structures were geometrically optimized, and E B of the metal atoms were calculated and annotated at the bottom of each structure in Fig. 2. Following the thermodynamic convention, the more negative E B the more thermodynamically stable the catalyst is. From the calculation results, it can be seen that the binding energies (|E B|) of metal Fe and the alkyne groups of GDY micropores are all larger than 7 eV, which indicates that the designed GDY-supported Fe DACs are energetically stable. As shown in Fig. S5, the binding energies of the iron atoms are mostly in the range of –8.00 to –8.40 eV, except for Fe2-GDY0, Fe2-GDY3, and Fe2-GDY4. The relatively stronger binding of Fe2-GDY0 can be attributed to the interaction between the two iron atoms with a distance of 2.430 Å. Compared to the Pyykkö covalent Fe–Fe single bond length of 2.320 Å, the calculated Fe-Fe distance suggests that, in addition to Fe–C bonding, there may be notable Fe–Fe interactions as well. 3.2 Geometry and spin relationship of GDY-supported Fe dual-atom catalysts Identifying spin states is a crucial step in studies related to spin state-dependent electrocatalysis. Experimental techniques commonly employed in the literature include X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), Mössbauer spectroscopy and temperature-dependent magnetization measurements. The energy position and fine structure of the X-ray absorption near-edge spectrum (XANES) are sensitive to the oxidation state and local electronic structure of the absorbing element [ 67 ]. In EPR, the magnitude and anisotropy of the g-tensor provide critical insights into the spin state and ligand field symmetry of paramagnetic centers, enabling spin state assignment through quantitative analysis of g-factor values [ 68 ]. Mössbauer spectroscopy further complements spin state characterization by resolving hyperfine interaction parameters, including isomer shift, quadrupole splitting, and magnetic hyperfine field, which correlate with electronic configuration and spin crossover phenomena [ 69,70 ]. These experimental observations can be systematically interpreted via spin-polarized DFT calculations, which serve as a fundamental theoretical framework for modeling spin-dependent electronic structures and validating spectral signatures [ 71 ]. 3.2.1 Depict of the spin state with three-dimensional spin density isosurface Spin density refers to the density difference between Alpha and Beta electron densities (ρ α – ρ β), indicating the distribution of unpaired electrons in three-dimensional space. From the spin density isosurface diagram (Figs. 3(a)–(d) and Fig. S6), it is observed that the unpaired electrons are primarily localized on the Fe atoms. These unpaired electrons on the iron atoms are more likely to interact with reactants or intermediates, particularly triplet O2 and other oxygen-containing intermediates, during the ORR process [ 24,37 ]. This interaction plays a role in modulating the reaction mechanism and enhancing the catalytic activity of both SACs and DACs. The carbon atoms adjacent to both FeI and FeII exhibit slight spin polarization, with opposite spin states compared to the neighboring iron atoms. Moreover, the spin state of the two iron centers aligns either in spin up (with purple isosurface surrounding both iron atoms) or in spin up and down (with both purple and blue isosurface surrounding each iron atom) depending on the relative positions of the metal atoms. In the Fe2-GDYn system, the co-presence of both spin-up and spin-down for each iron atoms are associated with AFM in Fe DACs. In contrast, DACs where both iron atoms exhibit the same spin states are attributed to FM. This suggests that the particular introduction strategy of a second metal atom in DACs alters the spin state of the active center atom. Further investigation is needed to understand the deliberate impact of the iron atoms on the magnetic properties of DACs. 3.2.2 Quantitative structure-spin relationship Spin density diagrams depicted the qualitative magnetic properties of Fe2-GDYn DACs. To figure out the structure-spin/magnetization relationship quantitatively, the spin populations as the integration of spin densities in the specific atomic spheres were deducted (see detailed values in Table S2). Firstly, a convergence of the magnetic ground state was simply executed with the parameters ISPIN = 2, and a default initial MAGMOM = NIONS × 1.0 for all the elements. The results show that when the perpendicular distance, d ⊥ ≥ 0.294 Å, the spin states of the two iron atoms are opposite, and the corresponding catalyst structures are Fe2-GDY1, Fe2-GDY3. When d ⊥ ≤ 0.034 Å, the spin state of the two iron atoms is identical, and the catalyst structures are Fe2-GDY0, Fe2-GDY2, Fe2-GDY9, and Fe2-GDY12 (Fig. 3(e)). However, within the intermediate range of d ⊥ from 0.034 to 0.294 Å, the spin states alternate between FM and AFM (with a net total spin population for the unit cell approximate to zero). For instance, in Fe2-GDY10, Fe2-GDY11, Fe2-GDY13, Fe2-GDY14, and Fe2-GDY15, the iron atoms exhibit alternating spin-up and spin-down states, whereas Fe2-GDY5, Fe2-GDY6, Fe2-GDY7, and Fe2-GDY8 feature both iron atoms with spin-up states. It is worth noting that, in Fe2-GDY4, the spin population of FeI is 0.014, with localized spin-up and spin-down densities on the same iron atom (Fig. S6), which can be attributed to planar 3d orbital splitting. 3.2.3 Couple-decouple shifting of the dual iron spin state To date, the understanding of the structure-activity relationship regarding spin population remains rather limited. Hence, in order to further explore the magnetic ground state, a more rigorous convergence was achieved with the parameter ISPIN set to 2, and the initial MAGMOM values of 3.0 and ±3.0 were adopted for iron atoms in the FM and AFM states, respectively. To evaluate the ground state of Fe2-GDYn, the total energy difference ∆E = E AFM – E FM was investigated as a criterion (Table S4). It was found that, with the exception of Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3, the ∆E values of the other structures fall within the so-called chemical accuracy range of 1 kcal mol–1 (0.043 eV). GDY is a two-dimensional material consisting of sp 2 and sp hybridized carbon atoms. The structure of GDY can be regarded as the insertion of diacetylene linkages (–C≡C–C≡C–) into one-third of the two sp 2-carbon atoms formed double bonds in the graphene structure [ 47,72 ]. GDY monolayer is a semiconductor with a direct band gap of 1.10–1.22 eV when using high-accuracy hybrid exchange-correlation functional or non-self-consistent GW calculation [ 73,74 ]. According to the presence of sp- and sp 2-carbon atoms, GDY structures show different types of bonding. Thus, between two sp 2-carbon atoms, a double bond is formed (i.e., σ + π); between two sp-carbon atoms a triple bond is formed (i.e., σ + 2π), and a single σ bond between sp-sp 2 carbon atoms [ 75 ]. Consequently, in contrast to graphene with a zero bandgap, the alternating occurrence of electron-localized σ bonds in GDY leads to a relatively higher degree of electronic localization. This unique feature endows GDY with a bandgap similar to that of silicon, which is around 1.11 eV. Accordingly, the number of intervals in the shortest responsive bond between iron atoms, defined as N σ, N σ+π, and N σ+2π, which respectively correspond to the number of C–C, C=C, and C≡C bonds, was considered as another promising descriptor. Meanwhile, N tot represents the sum of the quantities of these three types of bonds. In all the 16 Fe2-GDYn, only the two iron atoms in Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3 can be directly linked by Fe–C and Fe–Fe bonds, without any intervening carbon-carbon interaction. As a result, Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3 exhibit clear FM characteristics, with ΔE values of 0.3675 and 1.0557 eV (Table S5). Thus, the high spin state of the two structures can be attributed to Hund's rule of maximum multiplicity. In contrast, the |ΔE| values for the remaining structures are all below the chemical accuracy threshold of 0.043 eV. However, Fe2-GDY5 and Fe2-GDY8 with ΔE values of 0.0221 and 0.0187 eV, may have a higher likelihood of FM behavior, while Fe2-GDY1 and Fe2-GDY6, with ΔE values of –0.0249 and –0.0375 eV, may have a higher likelihood of AFM behavior. When defining the π-bond component as π% = (N σ+π + 2*N σ+2π)/N tot, it is observed that the remaining ten structures with smaller |ΔE| value all have π% ≥60% (Fig. 4 ). In other words, the delocalized π-electrons in these structures function like an electron reservoir, leading to coupled and conjugated spin states between the iron atoms, manifested by comparable spin population values in both the FM and AFM states. As a consequence, the FM and AFM states become indistinguishable, with the exception of Fe2-GDY8 [ 76–80 ]. For Fe2-GDY8, which possesses a π% of 66.7%, a similar higher likelihood of FM behavior is observed compared to Fe2-GDY5. Nevertheless, upon taking into account the Kohn-Sham DFT accuracies for many molecules are limited to 2–3 kcal mol–1 with presently-available functionals, it turns out that only Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3 display confirmed FM states with non-negligible ∆E values [ 81 ]. In light of the preceding discussion, it is advocated that the spin-correlated reaction mechanism warrants a more scrupulous exploration. The determination of the magnetic ground state of the bare catalyst poses a significant challenge. Moreover, dealing with the spin crossover, which has been scarcely addressed in the realm of heterogeneous catalysis, constitutes an even more formidable challenge [ 82,83 ]. When conducting an analysis of the electronic structure of GDY-supported catalysts, which represent a distinctive class of materials, particularly with regard to spin state analysis, it is of utmost importance to exercise prudently and avoid over-reliance on the default settings of software for the identification of the ground state. 3.3 Electron localization characteristic To gain a deeper understanding of the spin and bonding characteristics in Fe2-GDYn, a three-dimensional electron localization function (ELF) was calculated. This function describes and visualizes chemical bonds in the Fe2-GDYn xy plane across the z-axis, with the GDY plane set as the 0.00 height reference level. ELF measures the extent to which an electron's motion is confined within a specific region [ 84 ]. Conversely, electrons with the same magnitude of ELF value within a particular region are relatively delocalized and can be freely distributed [ 85 ]. Highly localized regions between C–C, C=C, and C≡C bonds, as well as around the –C≡C–C≡C– periphery, are observed both in the GDY plane (0.00 Å) and within a z-height of 0.50 Å (Fig. 5 and Fig. S7). The sp 2-carbon atoms in the small ring exhibit notable separation from the –C≡C–C≡C– linkage at the GDY plane. For Fe2-GDY0, a distinct Fe–Fe bonding range with an ELF value of approximately 0.30 is identified above the GDY plane, spanning from 1.00 to 1.80 Å (Fig. 5(a) ). Similarly, for Fe2-GDY3 (Fig. S7), the Fe–Fe bonding range extends from 1.40 to 1.80 Å above the GDY plane, attributable to the average d FeI and d FeII being about 0.40 Å higher than those in Fe2-GDY0. Generally, the ELF sections of the GDY skeleton above 1.00, 1.20, and 1.40 Å exhibit characteristics of conductive π-electron delocalization, as indicated by uniform coloring [ 86 ]. The clear σ bond separation between the two iron atoms in Fe2-GDY1 and Fe2-GDY8 at a height of 1.60 Å above the GDY plane, respectively, may contribute to variations in FM and AFM states. For the ten structures with indistinguishable FM and AFM states, represented by Fe2-GDY12, the strong resonance observed from 1.00 to 1.60 Å could be the fundamental reason for the long-range magnetic decoupling and averaging between the two iron atoms. The electron density difference (EDD) analysis was conducted for all structures by comparing the electron density vibrations of Fe2-GDYn with the corresponding bare GDY and two isolated iron atoms (Figs. S8 and S9). The regions of electron density depletion around the iron atoms indicate charge transfer from Fe to C. Conversely, the regions of electron density accumulation are associated with d-π coordination bonding localized in the Fe–C bond area. Additionally, the depletion observed along the Fe–Fe direction in Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3 further confirms the couple interaction between the two iron atoms. 3.4 Insight view of Fe–C bonding and spin splitting The PDOS and COHP analysis were performed using default magnetic ground state convergence. These analyses were conducted to qualitatively and quantitatively assess spin splitting and chemical bonding. The PDOS of the Fe 3d orbitals exhibits pronounced spin splitting with distinctly distributed peaks (Fig. S10) [ 87,88 ]. Based on the geometries of Fe2-GDYn, each iron atom can be approximated as being anchored at the center of a trapezoidal base formed by four sp carbon atoms, with the position of the metal center slightly deviating from the base and the plane of the carbon atoms (Fig. 2). Compared to the d orbital splitting observed in typical square planar and tetrahedral 4-coordinated d 8 complex, the Fe 3d orbitals in Fe2-GDYn demonstrate more pronounced orbital splitting and a higher spin state, featuring two unpaired electrons in the spin-up orbitals (Fig. 6(a) ). The relative d orbital energy levels are approximately determined by the d-band center below the Fermi energy level (E F). Notably, one of the spin-down e g (d x 2 -y 2 and d z 2) orbitals, is pushed up above the E F, while the remaining three occupied e g orbitals are further split into two groups, with one orbital pushed down into the strong bonding zone at a lower energy level. Similar orbital splitting is also observed in the t 2g orbitals. This pattern of orbital splitting remains consistent across all geometries (Fig. S10). Metal atoms supported on GDY may exhibit varying valence states due to factors such as the intrinsic metal, differences in local chemical environments, preparation methods, and reaction conditions, among others [ 72,89–93 ]. To gain deeper insights into the electronic configuration of Fe atoms in Fe2-GDYn, we employed the integration of PDOS diagrams to examine the electronic occupancy. By integrating the 10 d-orbitals of the Fe atom below the Fermi level, we assigned electrons to those orbitals where the absolute value of the integral area is exceeded 0.5. Our analysis revealed that the number of electrons occupying the d-orbitals is 8. Furthermore, we conducted a Local Orbital Bonding Analysis (LOBA) using the Multiwfn code in conjunction with CP2K, which showed that the oxidation state of iron is 0, further confirming the electronic configuration of Fe to be d 8 [ 94–96 ]. Additionally, the electronic configuration of Fe in Fe2-GDYn is consistent with the experimental findings of Li et al. [ 72 ]. This alignment with experimental results further supports the robustness of our computational findings and underscores the potential of Fe2-GDYn systems in catalytic applications. To provide a deeper understanding of spin splitting, the chemical bonding characteristics of the central iron atoms were analyzed. Specifically, the asymmetry in the planar coordination structure and the distortion in the axial coordination structure contribute to the spin splitting of the metal center. This coordination asymmetry can be further elucidated through –COHP analysis. For instance, trapezoidal short-edge carbon atoms, such as C3, C4 for FeI and C7, C8 for FeII, which have an average Fe–C bond length of ~1.88 Å, exhibit strong occupied bonding levels at lower energy regions (Figs. 6(b)-(e)). In contrast, the more distal pairwise carbon atoms, such as C1, C2 for FeI and C5, C6 for FeII, with an average Fe–C bond length of ~1.97 Å, show lower occupied bonding levels close to the E F. Additionally, the Bader charge population diagrams, which depict varying shades of blue for carbon atoms surrounding each iron atom (Fig. S11), as well as the variable population values (Table S6), and integrated COHP values (ICOHP, Table S7), further confirm the presence of coordination asymmetry both qualitatively and quantitatively. Metal element asymmetry in heteronuclear DACs inherently disrupts spin state uniformity. For instance, in FeMn-GDY0 the high-spin Mn (with spin population of 3.142) induces ferromagnetic coupling with Fe, yielding a Fe spin population of 1.990. Conversely, non-magnetic Cu (with spin population of –0.013) in FeCu-GDY0 suppresses Fe spin polarization to 1.931 (Fig. S12). 3.5 Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) mechanism study Electron spin plays a critical role in the catalytic activity and selectivity of atom-dispersed catalysts, particularly in reactions involving transition metal complexes with unpaired electrons [ 97,98 ]. To further elucidate the relationship between catalytic performance and spin states of DACs, we examined representative structures from our designed catalysts, specifically Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3, which exhibit pronounced FM states; Fe2-GDY1, representing the AFM state; and Fe2-GDY4, which displays indistinguishable FM and AFM states. These structures were investigated for their ORR mechanisms. The adsorption properties of triplet O2 on the above-mentioned structures reveal that FM dual-metal Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3 can directly dissociatively adsorb O2, with adsorption energies (E ads) of –3.296 and –3.766 eV, respectively. Such dissociation adsorption may facilitate the 4e– pathway, which promoting H2O production [ 97 ]. Conversely, O2 exhibits side-on and parallel adsorptions on Fe2-GDY1 and Fe2-GDY4, with E ads of –1.249 and –2.108 eV, respectively (Fig. S13). For a side-on adsorbed O2 on Fe2-GDY1, due to the steric hindrance of *OOH, the probability of a proton-coupling electron transfer (PCET) occurring at the adsorbed O site is extremely low. Thus, proceeding along the 4e– reaction pathway and ultimately producing H2O. Regarding *OOH configuration in Fe2-GDY4, the O site binding to Fe is exposed, which significantly enhances the likelihood of the O site PCET to generate 2e– pathway, resulting in the production of H2O2. The high degree of overlap between the unpaired electrons of FM iron and triple O2 in Fe2-GDY0 and Fe2-GDY3 results in strong dissociative interactions and varying ORR mechanisms. Meanwhile, the moderate interaction between O2 and Fe2-GDY1 may yield superior ORR performance due to the dynamic spin-flip effect (Table S8) [ 24,32 ]. The single-site ORR reaction coordinates indicate that the traditional ORR pathway, characterized by the rate-determining step (RDS) of *OH → H2O is observed for both Fe2-GDY1 and Fe2-GDY4, with energy barriers of 1.32 and 1.85 eV, respectively (Fig. 7 ). In contrast, direct dual-metal bonding sites in Fe2-GDY0 exhibit a higher RDS of 2.27 eV, likely due to strong interactions between oxygen species and Fe. However, carbon-bridged dual-metal sites in Fe2-GDY3 reduce the RDS from 2.04 to 1.45 eV, attributed to the co-reduction of two dissociative O atoms. The spin population characteristics of the primary RDS species, *OH, reveal that, in Fe2-GDY0, Fe2-GDY3 and Fe2-GDY4, unpaired electrons on the doublet OH are transferred to Fe, resulting in relatively higher RDS energies. Conversely, the unique interaction between OH and Fe in Fe2-GDY1, where paired electrons on O and Fe decrease the total spin, leads to a lower RDS free energy (Fig. S14, Table S9). This underscores the critical role of spin state interactions in governing the catalytic efficiency of ORR processes. The Fe2 structure with well-tuned Fe-Fe site distance can effectively regulate the spin state, thereby optimizing its interaction with O2 and enabling it to exhibit a high-power density comparable to that of commercial Pt/C in Zn-air batteries [ 99,100 ]. Additionally, the axial coordination of Fe sites can enhance ORR performance by moderating interactions between O2 and other oxygen-containing species, the bottom adsorption of O2, OOH, O, OH may also decrease the RDS energy (Table S10) [ 101–103 ]. The coupling effects between bimetallic sites, though complex, require further and comprehensive investigation, which will be the focus of our future research. 4 Conclusions Herein, in this study, a comprehensive qualitative and quantitative investigation was systematically carried out by using GDY as the dual-atom support without any pretreatment. The geometric properties of designed Fe dual-atom catalysts (DACs) are characterized by key descriptors such as the vertical heights of the iron atoms from the GDY base (d FeI and d FeII), with d ⊥ representing their elevation difference, and d║ denoting the straight-line distance between them, ranging from 2.430 to 14.015 Å. The iron atom binding energies generally range from –8.00 to –8.40 eV, with Fe2-GDY0 showing stronger binding due to its shorter Fe-Fe distance of 2.430 Å, indicating significant Fe–Fe interactions. The high-accuracy magnetic ground state is evaluated by using the energy difference as the criterion, with a deliberate setting of initial MAGMOM values and an energy convergence high-density k-mesh points of 9 × 9 × 1. The shift between the FM and AFM states of the dual iron spin system can be attributed to the short-range Fe-Fe interactions following Hund's rule of maximum multiplicity and long-range π-electron delocalization on the skeleton of GDY, respectively. Studies on Fe–C bonding and spin splitting reveal pronounced orbital splitting in the Fe 3d orbitals, with two unpaired electrons in the spin-up orbitals. This pattern of orbital splitting is consistent across different geometries and is influenced by geometric and chemical bonding asymmetries of the two iron atoms with an electronic configuration of d 8. Furthermore, the investigation based on representative Fe2-GDYn structures has revealed distinct ORR mechanisms and RDS free energies due to their unique geometric configurations and electronic properties. Our mechanistic investigations reveal that the spin-state landscape of bimetallic active sites can be strategically modulated through three synergistic factors: (I) fine-tuning the interatomic distance between bimetallic atoms; (II) incorporating metal elements with distinct spin-intrinsic properties; (III) engineering the local coordination symmetry of the two active sites. These fundamental principles establish a quantitative foundation for the rational design of next-generation catalysts with precisely tailored spin configurations. This is of particular significance for industrial processes that demand stringent control over multi-electron transfer kinetics, where the manipulation of spin states can potentially enhance catalytic efficiency and selectivity. We anticipate that this work will stimulate and encourage more extensive and in-depth studies on the spin states and spin transitions of S/DACs by researchers. Additionally, our group is further developing self-consistent calculations to assess the oxidation states and spin states of the metal atoms at the center of these catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Dual-atom catalysts (DACs), a natural extension of single-atom catalysts (SACs), have emerged as a prominent focal point in the field of heterogeneous catalysis, particularly in the context of chemical and energy conversion processes. Despite the fact that the catalytic activity of DACs is significantly modulated by the electronic structure of the catalyst, understanding how electron spin states are affected by variations in topology and geometric structure remains challenging and relatively unexplored. Herein, we propose the rational design of stable DACs composed of two iron atoms anchored on pristine graphdiyne (GDY), Fe2-GDYn. A comprehensive and systematic investigation was carried out to elucidate the electronic configuration and spin states involved in the deliberate convergence towards the magnetic ground state, with the aim of uncovering the structure-spin relationship. Through an in-depth analysis of spin populations, electronic localization/delocalization, and the chemical bonding characteristics of the central metal atoms and the GDY skeleton, it was revealed that the spin coupling between the two iron atoms is preponderantly dictated by adjacent short-range Fe-Fe interactions. Conversely, spin decoupling can be attributed to the long-range π-bond component within the linkage. Moreover, geometric and chemical bonding asymmetries were found to induce orbital and spin splitting in iron atoms possessing an electronic configuration of d 8. These findings provide important insights into the relationship between topology and spin, thereby presenting novel strategies for the rational design of spin-manipulated DACs.
